author: Rollmottle
content:
Every streaming service has a different number at which they will do normalization. If you are above that number and the user has normalization enabled, the service will turn the music down to match that number.

The immediate problems baked in:
1. Every service works differently. One cannot confidently shoot at a target that doesn’t really exist. So, just master the material for the material.
2. Not every user has normalization turned on. Thus, the material will be arbitrarily quiet next to other material that isn’t mastered to the target. So, just master the material for the material.
3. Not everybody consumes through streaming. Outside of a platform, the material needs to stand on its own. So, just master the material for the material.
4. Lots of modern music benefits sonically from being pushed into a limiter. Mastering below that short changes the material. So, just master the material for the material.

author: Edsel Holden
content:
Story time - I was asked to master a song that is above my paygrade, I was  super stoked to land the gig. I got the limited ref and the unlimited mix, and went to town doing “my thing” as usual. After some time I went for the A/B - and the ref was BLOWING my shit out of the water. To provide a little context, I have been mastering seriously for 6 years, and in the least ego driven way possible, usually always “my thing” beats whatever limited ref I am up against. I have not been in many scenarios where I can’t beat the ref. With this song that was not the case at all. On the advice shared here previously, I got in touch with the mixer and asked what was going on with his loudness chain. 

Dudes, it was so much. Two BOZ clippers, a gullfoss, stacked limiters - the works. However - the limited ref was dripping in vibe. The mixer bullseye’d this song. It was totally ON POINT and my chain was getting nowhere close. I considered going the route of screenshots and recreate the mixers madness step by step - but TBH - I did not want to drag the project through all that especially with me being brought on as a new ME to an already established team that is above my paygrade, and my ears and heart knew that the limited ref was right on the money anyway.

I needed a vote of confidence , so I asked a close friend (cough @Nomograph Mastering ) who is ahead of me in this game if it was acceptable for me to work from the limited ref. (showing my greenness here). A great word of advice came through - “The only rule is what gives the best final outcome.” - I made the call to work from the ref. The final chain was so simple - standard clip, equilibrium, limitless. 3 moves. Nothing going crazy. Got an over the top enthusiastic approval this morning, and am so freakin stoked about the whole thing, will probably get the whole project.

author: markmaclure
content:
You can read the patent for IRC here :https://patents.google.com/patent/US9225310B1/en?oq=Audio+limiter+system+and+method+izotope+US9225310B1
Basically the signal is processed multiple times with different attack and release times, then compared to the original signal. Each attack/release time is given a distortion and masking score and the best score is selected. The different IRC modes prioritize different types of scores (eg. IRC I prioritizes low pumping and distortion, IRC II is similar to IRC I but prioritizes transients more, etc). 
Izotope is a little cagey on the exact process they use to arrive at each IRC mode, but the manual does a pretty good job of explaining how each mode feels. IRC IV Transient is basically a multiband version of the other IRC modes that prioritizes transients, although Izotope says IRC V is its first multiband limiter in Ozone, so there is maybe more to the story there

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Hey @Gerhard Westphalen I don’t have time to read the replies so a quick summary of how I do it, sorry if it’s repeating 

1) Don’t take the limiter off, on many modern projects the music will be unrecognizable without it and it's what the artist approved. I typically reduce the limiting amount around 2dB, sometimes more sometimes less. I’ll also re balance clipper and limiter relationships

2) Don’t do any pre-emptive processing with the exceptions perhaps of paying a little extra care if it’s a project with heavy sibilance. Don’t mono the bass, don’t change the EQ etc 

3) Make a single WAV file of each side, and a set of timing notes that show where each track starts and the length so the cutting engineer can place the track banding / markers

4) I like to highlight anomalies that may present a challenge for cutter but it’s not necessary

author: Paris Lee
content:
I’m not really qualified to speak from any technical standpoint of anything discussed here, especially among the giants and don’t want to look stupid …but as someone who DJ’d House, Techno, Drum and Bass etc back in the late 90’s as a teenager in LA on Vinyl (I’m 45 now), watched the transfer to CD’js…(no idol of mine has touched a vinyl in 20 years) and masters for modern EDM artists, I feel like I can speak with some authority about, I dunno, *something*…Back in those days, I guess Ill just say there were a lot of factors that influenced what sounded so good about that era, and what producers did then. The dynamics, combined with the *type of low frequency* content of those genres at that time, along with DJ’s who knew what the fuck they were doing, along with sound crews who worked the rave circuit and were continually hired and worked with the same DJ’s, all contributed so much to this magic rave Vinyl era.
There’s nothing that touched those deep kickass lows back then, But That was the style! 
So much has changed. Producers back then got their loudness from pushing analog desks into the red, Simple Mackie desks, stuff like that. But We moved to an all digital world. I remember when the first pioneer digital DJ mixers came out, I’d put a vinyl on and just be like…this is shit! where’s my headroom?!?! the frequency distribution of the music has also changed, DJ’s also got more concerned with jumping up and down and clapping rather than mixing and gain staging. Clubs started putting limiters on the systems 
Most of these kids doing EDM at high levels-really don’t even need ME’s at all! Their mix busses are so super complex. If they took that stuff off, I’d be totally lost. But they like a little analog processing in a lot of cases. Loudness, they *don’t need*
Clipping, limiting, whatever, it’s the modern thing- If i can help I can- and I tell them not to change a thing- just back off the limiter until the exact moment where the track loses the vibe. Then I go.

Just for reference, the convo was to restrict my approach to one band of EQ, Q of no sharper than .7 and maybe a low shelf. That's it. And a limiter.

Since then I've done at least over 100 songs, many of which are out in the world and/or on their way to release. So a decent time to circle back with some insight. However, compared to more experienced ears on here I am still a baby.

Extremely powerful challenge from Ruairi, and it really made me think in broad terms about what EQ is doing, what my goals are when using it, and how each part relates to another. And what you gain or lose when making a move. I would highly recommend it, and found it very very hard. It's non-trivial to make things sound better when you actually hear what's happening.

Of course for work where I'm being paid I'm not only restricting to one band, I do whatever is needed but even so many times I would prefer that. It felt like "learning scales" but for mastering in a way. And loudness really is down mostly to EQ, as far as I can tell!

author: Rollmottle
content:
nah, fuck -1 or -2. theoretically the lower the ceiling, the less risk there is of intersample peaks happening upon conversion to MP3 or some other lossless format streamers use to stream audio to your device. even if there are ISP's, they usually light up a meter but are inaudible. i live at -0.5db for most everything. sometimes i'll go to -0.3db if it's something that is pop oriented (this is where i landed for @thejadenmejia's single for example). i think a lot of the panic about it is overblown. in the real world, clients like their shit loud.

as far as distro goes, i know some are starting to accept higher res files or even accepting multiple files. my deliverables have always been 96/24 and 44/16. I've recently started including 44/24's. i've always discouraged submitting anything other than 44/16 because who knows what some of these services are doing with SRC and dither, but i think with the advent of high res and lossless delivery, you are well-advised to submit the higher bit-rate files nowadays. all that said, with something like 44/24 you are probably pretty safe from getting your shit munched down-funnel.

author: Slow Hand
content:
When it comes to loudness, a big unlock happened for me when I realized that a lot of perceived loudness comes from the frequency balance of instruments or groups. There's a sort of "center of gravity" for the frequency of instruments. Individual instruments did not need as much low end as I once thought. I realized that I could push more energy up into the mids and upper-mids. Instruments could be leaner and biting. Much more than I thought tolerable. This has a few positive effects:

1. The sounds will cut more and be articulate in the mix (if desired).

2. Low-end buildup is the first thing that's going to hit your limiter. Shifting the energy up the frequency spectrum buys you more space before your limiter kicks in. Thus your overall mix can be louder.

3. Your low-end instruments will no longer compete to feel powerful. Therefore they do not need to be as loud in an absolute/voltage sense. Meanwhile, your midrange-y instruments that were once lean and bite-y in isolation are supplemented by your low-end instruments and feel whole again.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content: Also, every way of shaving transients is different. Different limiter time constants. Different clipper curves. Saturation or not. Compression or not. Multiband implementation or not. a certain number of dB one way is not the same as the same number of dB some other way.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
@Rollmottle already gave a great answer here. I want to re-state and co-sign what he posted 

1. Don't try and remove what you can't hear. Never going to end well. There is no general rule sub 30hz so don't try and preemptively deal with something if you're not even sure it's an issue
2. If you do need to deal with a low end issue, deal with it at the source, instead of the 2-mix if you can
3. If you're dealing with it at the 2-mix level, gentle shelves will do less harm than steep cuts

Ok. Now to a thornier aspect of your question - does throwing away super low end information help us with loudness?

As I’ve said many times here our typical goal is not just maximum loudness. The goal is really high perceived loudness, and low measured loudness (to avoid being turned down too much by normalization), all while remaining musical and true to the intent of the song

Perceived loudness is primarily driven by arrangement (less elements better), distortion (more distortion makes things feel louder but at obvious cost) and frequency content (special attention needs to be paid to the 1500 to 6000 region I mentioned the other day). Super low end content doesn’t have too much of a direct effect on how we perceive loudness but of course it does have second order effects - huge lows will cause limiters to overwork and we’ll get into trouble with things sounding smashed sooner than we’d like

Ok, but what of measured loudness? Here it pays to have an understanding of how LUFS are actually calculated. I don’t know if there’s a neat summary video somewhere Dan Worrall style, if so please link it in folks. The definitive doc on LUFS measurement is here 

https://www.itu.int/dms_pubrec/itu-r/rec/bs/R-REC-BS.1770-5-202311-I!!PDF-E.pdf

author: eschirtz
content:
I hear you Ruairi, and ultimately you gotta make your own call on this. 

But I just wanna reassure you that our business is built around serving your type of workflow. Even if 99% of users don't give a shit about the perfect playback, we do. That's why we have that "lossless" switch. We'll never switch to AAC due to bandwidth issues.

The "constant upgrades" are often due to the ever changing landscape of browsers. Each client is often on a different browser, different device and different internet connection. It's our job to understand that landscape and push fixes to ensure we get perfect playback across all environments. 

That's part of the reason we built the iOS app, to be able to provide a more consistent playback experience when browsers themselves are the limiting factor, and so that clients can listen offline to take the network out of the equation. But I totally understand that you can't really ask a client to install another app on their iPhone. 

To my knowledge, Samply is still the only platform that lets clients stream full resolution lossless AND gapless track transitions in a browser. It's a really tough engineering challenge, but ultimately the backbone of our entire business. We're committed to continuing to solve this problem and evolve with the technology available.

author: Edsel Holden
content:
I will share words that are not mine (these words belong to @Nomograph Mastering )

Context is important here. This is an email that Nomogrpah wrote back to a client that said "Hey I love the master so much but I am a bit worried about how much it might get turned down ?" or something to that effect 

Response was 

"Glad you are feeling the master!

Re the level thing that is a complicated question. A few thoughts

Not everyone has loudness normalization turned on. It also doesn’t exist on Smart TVs, many streaming web interfaces etc

The different services all have different level norm targets (and even different settings within just Spotify) - and they change pretty regularly

In terms of absolute level when normalization is active what matters is arrangement (dense mixes sound quieter than sparse/spacious mixes), EQ (bright/mid range forward mixes sound louder than dark) and distortion levels (clipped/distorted mixes feel perceptually louder than clean). If I make a master a dB louder in mastering using just limiting for example, they just turn it down a dB more when it’s level normed.

So what does all of this mean? It means that every song has sweet spot where the EQ/tone, the arrangement and the overall clipping/limiting level works best and communicates the intent. That’s what we aim for.

You can use a site like loudnesspenalty.com to see what will happen but it will just drive you crazy and the only real way to meaningfully alter the result is to change the arrangement/mix or overall EQ a lot. On release day you can find 1000 records that are louder than yours if you want to.

If being the loudest is the intent - game everything listed above and you can “win”. If doing your unique thing and communicating a song and a performance is the goal then I think you are there!"

(posted with Nomographs permission)

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yeah. I immediately change the frequency graph to *Log* or *Extended Log*. This allows me to see the low-end and midrange with more resolution. It's the same reason most EQ graphs keep the octaves evenly spaced so that 50% of your freq graph isn't 10kHz and up. It gives you more resolution for the notes in the lower octaves.

As for FFT size or window shape, I never change it, but as Ruairi alluded to it requires an understanding of the physical limitations of FFT's. 

In short if you want very fine frequency information displayed you can change the window size and lose rhythmic information. But it you want very precise rhythmic visualization you have to sacrifice how much frequency information the FFT can display. So the ideal setting ultimately depends on what problem you're trying to solve.

author: Berlin
content:
I would suggest not changing the program material/main master too much and just preparing the sides, delivering one file per side, along with the PQ/Cut sheets with the track marker times (again one cut sheet per side), doing the QC listen down after export, and delivering with your approval.

I think backing off the limiter is sometimes OK, but very program material dependent. Yanking the limiter off a hot pop master might change things too much, for example.

Additionally, whoever is cutting the lacquer, will likely be doing their own adjustments as they see fit.. so if you are concerned about it translating properly, I would get with a lacquer engineer that you know and trust so you can have a dialogue about it, if needed.

That being said, in my experience, great sounding projects/masters will sound good on vinyl if the cutting engineer knows what they are doing… no matter how much you try to help with the PreMaster.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
As a follow up to this (most of us here know it, but I see it is a common misconception out in the Wild Wild West):

32bit will allow any over 0s to be represented in the file — if you print at 24bit and there are overs, those overs go to 0, it’s not exactly clipping like we might think of it but like it.

The tricky part is people can monitor above 0 in their DAW since it is at 64bit usually, then if they print at 24bit the overs are sent to 0

author: Zach Hughes
content:
So this is straight from Spotify's website and obviously nobody really abides by it but I just want to know if theres a 'why':    *Target the loudness level of your master at -14dB integrated LUFS and keep it below -1dB TP (True Peak) max. This is best for lossy formats (Ogg/Vorbis and AAC) and makes sure no extra distortion’s introduced in the transcoding process.
If your master’s louder than -14dB integrated LUFS, make sure it stays below -2dB TP (True Peak) to avoid extra distortion. This is because louder tracks are more susceptible to extra distortion in the transcoding process.*

First of all Edsel, congrats!! Sounds like you crushed it. Warms my heart to see others in here succeeding.

In some ways being very new has given me a great creative armor, I am not afraid to lose and therefore do not feel bad or something if the ref is a better starting point than my chain or if I am doing very little.

I am fascinated in your perspective as someone who is a pros pro but in between where I am and where Ruairi is.

I’ll land the plane here…it seems like the fact that this song was “above your pay grade” sort of played into the fact that you were maybe seeking Ruairi’s approval to use that limited ref?

From my understanding (and please correct me if I'm wrong), what I've seen and tried De-Clip on is audio that is already clipped and distorted. In this case, speeding up the master before dither just introduced actual sample peaks in a 32bit file, which can represent them. So there wasn't any "clipping" going on, it was just a matter of...how do we get the file to a similar loudness at 24bit to deliver without it sounding awful? I suppose you could try the de-clip after limiting (which was introducing distortion).

But...a legendary human who doesn't want to be known as the speed up guy  helped me out with some sorcery, so it's solved (and honestly I know sorta what was happending but have no clue how he actually did it)

AND the artist is super pumped, loves the new version so it's a win

As far as the tips -- I'm definitely in the "leave everything on except the final limiter camp" if you are delivering a lim and non-lim...depending. author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
In modern record making clipping and limiting on the buss is a huge part of the overall sound and feel of a record. Kendrick for example never heard his productions, mixes or masters without it. Clipping has an energy in the kicks and snares that was built a certain way, limiting has rounding and smoothing characteristics and often "holds" the track in a particular way. You can't just bypass one , or the other or both without huge changes in groove, balance, tone and feel. (Swapping limiters for something *safer* can be equally damaging) 

What does clipping actually do? It creates square waves at the extreme (for the duration of the clipping)

What is a square wave? It is a fundamental with a bunch of odd harmonics trailing off in level

What happens when you low pass the square wave at the converter reconstruction filter, lathe low pass etc? It is no longer a square wave

Does cutting this no longer square wave to a disc for brief periods present challenges and cause extra momentary distortion? Yes

Is that trade off worth while? I believe so and have itterated on this belief across hundreds and hundreds of projects cut and pressed to vinyl and then compared carefully with the original digital files

author: Rollmottle
content:
I’ve found it easier to separate the tonal decisions from loudness decisions. I take the limiter out of the equation when I am making tonal decisions. So in my case, it's a simple bypass of with processing vs. without to make the decisions against the mix. This is inherently level matched. This gets trickier with dynamics processing but that’s a simple offset of the processed mix. That’s all happening on the object in my DAW without need for additional plugins or routing. Since I am rarely compressing anyways, this is a low friction way of judging the moves against the mix. 

When I’m happy with that, I’ll print the pre-lim and then load it up on another track to do the limiting. When I’m happy with the limiting, I have a quick action to create an A/B track where I can load the hot mix or mix to see if I’m as loud or louder than it. 

None of this is by number or meter. It’s all by ear.

author: Øra Mastering
content:
I always end up chasing my tail when separating tonal and loudness. If I get the right tonal balance first, then everything shifts around when adding loudness/limiting. To me all limiters and limiter styles within have different tones, at least if I’m limiting more then a couple of dB. For that reason I always start with finding the right limiter/style that keeps or changes the tonal balance the way I want (too bright mix = dark limiter, dull mix = bright limiter, great mix = limiter that keeps the balance when pushed ect.). Once I have the loudness and given the tonal balance a gentle push in the right direction with the limiter, I get the track over the finish line with eq or other tools in front of the limiter. 

This is not meant as criticism of your approach, I just haven’t cracked that code.
Hats of to you for making that work!

author: ALXCPH
content:
& 

"Beyond what Storm Mastering already said (i.e. non TP limiting ignore a good quarter of the signal, never limited audio in the first place. Given the same GR and delicate harmonic content, the antialiased version will sound better, measure better, preserve transient details better and far more reliably prevent overshoots). 

Non oversampled limiters are strictly speaking aliasing machines with erratic overshoot control. A "lofi" special effects adding things that weren't there before.

Put harmonic stuff into them and out comes inharmonic stuff. Sounds harder, faster and fresher. Not unlike a bit-crusher or SR decimator. In fact, the crusher or SR decimator will likely sound more controlled and offer more creative control over this valuable "digitalitis" than an aliased limiter.

Try adding 12bit crusher or SR decimator to the signal, and then have a properly antialiased limiter do its job smoothly, and musically. Gives the best of both worlds: metallic "spice" plus smooth, harmonic and effective overshoot protection.

Nothing wrong exploiting and enjoying the sound of inharmonic distortion, it often works great at beefing up boring drums and percussions. The metallic sound of aliased non-linearities is a tool in itself. I love 12bit(ing) my drums for better freshness, for sharper transients. Just don't confuse it with better preservation of the original, it's a special effect irreversibly changing the signal. "

author: masteredbyjack
content:
In my experience (again, caveated by it being rather limited compared to some on here), a gentle shelf wins most of the time.

This isn’t quite like soothe, but I’ve found success in certain situations using the weiss ds1-mk3 in the low pass mode, so it is only working on the area below the filter (as I understand it, and it appears to me). This seems to my ears to not have the bad multiband smearing problems of say fabfilter mb, etc

In situations where the dynamics down there are out of whack and you need to control the groove better it can really work great, but that specific plugin has odd release characteristics that take time to understand. That same flexibility can allow some subtle control down there that can actually accentuate the groove and fix your problems at the same time.

As with everything, there are trade offs, it can make the low end sound odd if not careful, and you really need a room that is accurate down there to judge it well I think (now that I’m in my current setup I can very clearly hear when it is helping or hurting)

author: Deleted User
content:
I would recommend separating mixing and mastering into another task from composition and arrangement. 

Printing all the instrumentation before moving onto mixing process can help you separate your brain a bit too. I also usually “save as” the session and name it this way

Artist - Songtitle Mix YYYYMMDD

the challenge in doing everything yourself is splitting the brain. once you get that together, it becomes easier. Limiting the Mix process into one to three days maximum can also help overthink less. After producing, you’ve heard the song so many times and it will be very easy to start second guessing.

CLA said “a mixer’s greatest weapon is our fresh perspective”. And it’s probably the same for mastering engineers too. Switching modes takes practice, and it can’t be done without practicing it at least in my experience. What helped me personally is mixing less while producing. Not putting too much time into processing individual elements unless I know exactly what I’m doing next. I try not to troubleshoot and figure out why the mix isn’t there yet because the arrangement isn’t done yet. 

How could I possibly make the drums work with vocals if the vocals aren’t there yet?

author: Slow Hand

Eh, who are these people and what does it matter to any of us what they think? Do they have any bearing on what the rest of us do? It sounds like Dave may be in a bubble of mastering engineer discourse where these advocates for massive dynamic range have an outsized voice. Clearly most of the world has moved on and don't heed the opinions of these people advocating for massive dynamic range.

Competitive loudness is a skill that we all have to learn, but people regularly push it too far and the best mixes will still crumple if they're pushed beyond their limit. Some records would have been better if people exercised restraint with how hard they push loudness. You can overcook loudness and you can undercook it as well.

As with so many things, the optimal solution is context dependent and somewhere in the middle. Neither too loud nor too quiet. You simply use your ears and do what's best for the record.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
What comes to mind quickly is:

1. Listen to the file after the export from master session (many of us do this in RX)

2. Consider what deliverable is needed (default for me is to deliver sample rate of what it came in at, 24 bit).

3. Consider how high your output ceiling should be based on the type of arrangement, etc. True Peak could play a role in this depending on the type of record

4. If there are alts, make sure they are aligned and exactly the same length as the main mix (again easy to check length in RX)

5. If you are doing SRC (say they need a 48k and 44k 16bit deliverable) check the SRC file as well to ensure that the SRC did not introduce any overs — it will quantize them to zero if you dither after but best to check still

author: Conah Tucker
content:
Hey folks! Following on from this, had a bit of time today to do some more testing, I've done a pink noise test today. 1 track 3 different loudnesses 5db apart. Uploaded the different loudnesses separately too.

Finds: (please note this is off of web TikTok, app TikTok tests will come soon)
• -4.6db overall (planning on testing this more in depth, but occurred 4 times on the 4 different audios I uploaded)
• Int LUFS -7.4 down to -13.3 (for this specific case).
• 5db differences remain.
• Brickwall eq at 16khz (this was tested on many different videos).
• The different levels uploaded separately did not change their respective loudnesses compared to the full noise track. So dynamic sections of track shouldn't boost if uploaded as a separate sound to TikTok.
• No compression.
• General audio quality does drop.

Things that come to mind:
•  Common 3rd party video editing apps (such as capcut) and how they affect audio
• The level control TikTok users have and how that affects audio (in terms of peak/loudness and referring back to the -4.6db peak mentioned earlier)


I'll run some more tests when I get the time to.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
My guess (and it’s a guess I don’t use sequoia) is that Em is “clipping” by using 32 or 64 bit in the DAW (what they all run at) — when you print at 24 or 16bit it will quantize away the overs (so any sample over 0 goes to 0).

Shockingly you can actually clip off a lot of level this way (I dislike the sound and would always choose to use a limiter but from what I’ve seen it doesn’t sound like awful digital clipping)

An issue I’ve run into often enough to care — when people take off a limiter but print at 24 bit and there are samples at 0 — they are going over since the plugins on the mix bus have internal headroom — I once had a bud taking off 6db this way (unintentionally) on the non-lim prints and it actually sounded okay (not good or recommended, but okay)

Of course on our end we cannot tell if the non-lim with samples at 0 is actually this (it could be a clipper, whatever) without knowing the mixer and asking.

The solve is to print non-lim at 32bit float but that’s not always possible (and if the mix is not hot going into the final limiter with over 0s it doesn’t really matter)

If I’m wrong on any of this someone please correct

author: Øra Mastering
content:
That makes sense, thanks for the explanation. Reading this, I don’t think we’re miles appart. I used to have one «default» limiter and focus all my moves in front of that, also adding limiter/loudness as the last step. When doing so, I always found myself having to tweak the moves (that I already had «perfectly» dialed in) because everything would change when adding the final limiter. That’s when I would be chasing my tail 😅
Now I start with getting the limiter right for the song and then doing eq moves as the second step. This way it it a lot less back and forth for me. I should say I only use one limiter at the time and the limiters I audition with are dmg limitless, fabfilter pro-l2 and Ozone maximizer, with styles I know well. Dmg usually gets used on acoustic and jazz, pro-l2 & ozone for pop/rock. If it is music with vocals I find different styles can really change the way the vocals are percieved, so it’s mostly chosing the style that support the vocals best that is the goal. Using two minuttes to get the right limiter from the start saves me time and uncertainty down the road, and in some cases let’s me use less eq to get the desired result.
There are many roads to Rome as they say, I was just interested in yours bc whenever I tried that it ended in a lot of second guessing (for me!). 

Do you find yourself having to add more eq when adding limiter at the end to keep the tonal balance you have acheived?

author: Øra Mastering
content: I work both hybrid and itb. When working hybrid, I try to keep the same settings for a whole album and do eq, de-essing and level automation pre analog if needed (on individual tracks). On some albums, for me, there is no way around tweaking analog settings per track, but I try to avoid it. When printing the album I use the print-time to casually listen to the album from start to finish to catch stuff I would like to adjust (one track lacks impact ect.). Final limiter is always post analog print and I do not print hot. This makes revisions a breeze 97% of the time, unless there is a new mix of course. Also easy to back of a limiter without reprinting if the client wants more dynamics or I want a more dynamic vinyl pre-master. Hope that made sense.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Hey. There’s nothing wrong with putting EQs and limiters on your master buss as you mix. A little bit of EQ or a lot of limiter is alright.

The answer here is to mix *into* your limiter. You don’t want to mix the entire song and then slap a limiter on at the end for loudness. As you’ve discovered that will mess up the balances that you’ve spent so much time getting right. You want to ease the final limiting in as you’re building the mix.

I usually start a mix by pulling my limiter down a few dB. Enough to get everything starting to touch the limiter. To get the loudness in the ballpark.

Then I’ll push into it a little more so that I’m starting to get some gain reduction. Certain instruments may begin to get pushed down or distorted in a way I don’t like. Maybe the kick is hitting the limiter too hard, so I bring it’s level down and then lower my limiter some more.

Continue this process of adjusting balances into your limiter as you mix until you’ve got the loudness where you want it. Usually I’m checking in on my limiter a few times throughout the mix to see if I can push it harder without penalty. When I hear it distort in a way that I don’t like I back off.

Hope that helps some.

author: Berlin
content:
I keep it simple. No oversampling. Flip between modes (Hard clip, soft clip, etc) to see what gets you a better result for the program material. Like with anything, there is not a simply quantifiable reason for why some modes work and others don't, changing from song to song. Listen carefully and use your ears. 

I like to use Standard Clip for highly transient material, clipping off those really high peaks to take some of the work off of the proceeding limiter. But it is very easy to get audible clipping and distortions if you go too far (if that not is not your desired result), so keep an ear out! The meter doesn't help you with that, even if it doesn't *look* like you're clipping very much.

author: ALXCPH
content:
Found an interesting thread on oversampling, aliasing & limiters. 
Here are some out of context quotes i enjoyed reading. 

"Don't forget a simple thing about limiters : if you engage oversampling, they detect bigger peaks and apply more GR.

That means the biggest difference is not the oversampling itself, but the fact that the limiter works way harder. 
On complex material, dialing a limiter "perfectly" means getting as close as possible to artifacts without hearing them, as usually a limiter working cleanly (by that I mean the lowest distortion) is a too slow limiter and you hear pumping and loss of punch. So you get closer to the danger zone, some distortion is well hidden by the signal and you're happy. If after that, you engage oversampling, it can add one or two dB of GR and those "just hidden behind the signal artifacts" become utterly obvious."

author: Will Melones
content:
All I know is that a lot of folks think Spotify doesn’t have a limiter—it only turns *down* loud masters when normalization is enabled. In fact Spotify definitely DOES have a limiter, and if you deliver a master below -14 LUFS it will be turned UP, and anything over 0 will be smashed (only when normalization is enabled).

There is also a 3-level setting for volume when normalization is on, and the app tells you that sound quality *will* be affected at the loudest setting. Not sure how this works in real life.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content:
I generally don't do that, FWIW. 

The best producers I work for occasionally ask something specific (e.g. "we started putting Bloom on our mix bus, how do you feel once you recall it and start tweaking?"). Or for e.g. a drum bus w/ heavy processing they'll ask if I'm good to work w a stereo stem instead of the multis. But even that's a fairly rare exception. Mostly they've done what they like, they send it how they want to send it, and they want me to mix it.

There's one producer I work for who regularly wants more feedback. I find it hard to give. Because I wasn't there in the room, I don't know the limitations of the session. It's not helpful to try and impose my harmonic vocabulary or arrangement preferences on someone else's, and the sessions are never unmixable even when I don't think they come from an ideal starting point. And on a fundamental level I really don't like telling other people what to do or how to feel.

author: Grover
content:
Well, a great sounding cut starts with good performances, mixes, etc. etc. just like any other medium. 

That said, if you've got a nice digital master (and these dont need to be loudenated like digital masters - the cutting engineer gets the level going onto the disk) then a cutting engineer isnt only massaging things so it can get cut, ideally not changing the sound. They may use a little eq, acceleration limiters or elliptical filters but they generally arent looking to change the basic sound, only make sure the head can cut it. The lathes collection of amps, the gear they have to accomplish this and the cutter head, the RIAA curve etc. will all heavily affect the sound, though that's probably obvious given that it's vinyl. The lathe amp/head combo can really make a pretty big difference. 
The Neumann VMS70's and 80's sound totally different from a Scully/Westrex with tube amps for example.

author: Grover
content:
Surely there's something to learn from the history though yes? Cutting is what the profession of mastering used to be and digital is not wholly removed. We can certainly take learnings from our history while embracing modern methods. Cutting good vinyl is also respect for the folks who work on it and the artists who want their music conveyed appropriately across mediums. 

I have no problem making stuff massively loud with zero limiting and small amounts of soft clipping, and still retaining tons of transient peaks. I prefer this sound to heavy limiting at the master stage where the program material audibly hits the limiter and the soundstage and sense of headroom collapses. To me, the limiter is optional, but I do understand many use it before they acquire the skills to work without it. 

That said, I also was taught that in genres where its appropriate (Imagine Dragons, Hip hop, EDM, etc.) that those sounds should go in at the production or mixing stage. At the mastering stage I was taught to do no harm, and only to enhance what was present. In my work pushing more than a few dB into a limiter to affect the groove of a piece does not track with my understanding of doing as little to change the sound as possible. But of course, it all depends on the project. My clients who make very mainstream pop/youtube music don't particularly care if I radically editorialize as long as it sounds good and serves the tune. 

There's also something to be said for music which needs to be quiet. Not all music should be loudenated to within an inch of its life. Not all music needs quiet and intimacy. I think of we hold the pursuit of "the program material's individual requirements to be king" we cannot then also dismiss vinyl as unimportant or say that one MUST always do things a particular way.

author: masteredbyjack

My 2 cents -- going forward those of us who think of mastering as "finishing" instead of "mastering" in the traditional sense might be very well equipped. I know Edsel you are similar -- but when I let go of the "this is what mastering IS" mindset, and leaned into the "this is the box in front of me I have to operate within", things got much better. Acceptance.

Is it mastering if I only work from a stereo file? A limited REF? Tearing apart an mp3 bounce with AI and remaking it? An Ableton session? I say yes to all if we are the ones getting the record across the line. 

That said, the traditional approach is IMO the best for many reasons, but in some sense just having a stereo file is an almost arbitrary restriction based on how projects are made and shared (though a good one). But as technology evolves and shifts, best to be on the cutting edge of knowing how to make a lot of situations work -- I bet the winners will be those who do

author: Jeremy Klein
content:
Ok so from what i can tell, Apple Digital Masters, (previously called MFiT), is basically just a series of guidelines that wants you to 

a) deliver the highest res wave file possible without up sampling
b) avoid clipping (so true peak + reduced ceiling + monitor any clipping through the tools they provide you)
c) preview that after your wav is encoded for Apple Music, you make sure it still sounds good. (the Master for Itunes droplet tool they give you)

If you want that "Apple Digital Master" badge, on the track, you likely have to get it done by someone certified to do an ADM master.

But the type of record it is, how important those ISPs are to manage based on possible codec conversion to streaming, all of it is way too complicated a balance to just conclude from one file on an instagram story

He's making it seem like a free lunch -- more ISPs more volume! -- when it's really a balance of factors to consider

author: Nicky Howard
content:
I do something a bit like this! 

When working at the mix's native sample rate, my main limiter is usually set to -0.3 dB FS. If ISP control is needed, following this, I have a second limiter all zeroed with the ceiling set between 0 to +1 dB TP.

Delta mode on the second limiter is good for checking what this does. 

When the second limiter's ceiling is the same as the first (or the first is in TP mode), the triggering is usually rhythmic to the music. It's obvious and can eat transients. When at 0 dB TP, it's usually triggering much more randomly, making the ISP control much less obvious. 

If the music is slammed and the second limiter is too aggressive at 0 dB TP, that's when I push up towards +1 dB TP. TDR Limiter 6 is good for this as the ceiling goes positively. It's just not so good for actual limiting!

author: Berlin
content:
I did this recently for a rush master that had no time to go back to mix, reverb tail on the vocal cut off after a measure of the last note.

I stemmed out the vocal in RX, brought it back in to WAVELAB, full wet on vintage verb EQ and time until it sounded close to what i was hearing on the MST, and then mixed it down to the right level in parallel to the mix.. had my final limiter on the “output” summing bus of wavelab.

Worked great and no one knew the wiser.

author: Rob Domos
content:
To me, this oversampling stuff isn’t a case of “more is better but the massive computational increase for that little gain is silly”. If I thought it was better I’d just sell a kidney and get a super computer, but I think oversampling above quad rate actually sounds worse. Been puzzling as to why for a while. 

I’m confident at this point that it’s not that I like the sound of aliasing. Oversampling that high has this smoothing effect like when you crank the noise reduction on a photo that isn’t coming from the LPF or the decreased distortion. I’m a Dunning Krueger case when it comes to DSP math, but from the surface amount that I’ve drilled into it, it seems that there’s at least a handful of different ways of adding samples to a signal and none of them are completely free of cost to the signal. It’s possible that maxing that process to the ceiling incurs more of that cost.

author: Moses Mastering
content:
So, in most cases, you can go over 0 dB in your DAW if you're working in 32-bit (or higher) precision, and you won’t necessarily hear the clipping. This is because the internal audio engine can handle peaks above 0 without immediate distortion—it’s all about floating-point processing magic.

Now, whether the audio gets normalized to stay under 0 dB depends on what happens during export. Sometimes, what you're seeing in the DAW or Ozone meters isn’t exactly what ends up in the final file—especially if there's a limiter, normalization, or post-processing involved. It’s even possible that the version you’re analyzing wasn’t actually the one that was officially released. Happens more often than you’d think!

That said, it’s not unusual to see mixes or masters that are technically clipping more so going over 0... in tools like Ozone or the DAW but sound fine due to the flexibility of floating-point processing. I’m not saying this is a best practice—but I’ve definitely played around with it. I’ve even intentionally clipped files way past 0 dB, re-exported them, and compared them to cleaner versions. They sounded different, but at that point, I found myself asking, “Why am I trying to squeeze one more dB of loudness out of something that’s already crushed and competitive?” Classic overthinking, right?

Anyway, back to your question: I think what you’re seeing is a product of the DAW working internally at 32- or 64-bit, so it can handle those overs without clipping during processing. Then, during export, maybe they normalized it, maybe they fixed it later, maybe it did just didn't sound distroted haha... or maybe that’s just not the real released version at all. Who knows?  I would not lose sleep over it and also know what you have seen is not a "secret" that your missing haha.

author: Ted Whitten Media
content: Yeah they're just using peak/RMS on the metering section, the k system has colored ranges on it. So that's actually going out of Ozone like that. But as mentioned before, it's floating point, so no worries there. There's got to be some gain staging after that, 5 db of steady clipping would sound like it's being run through a fuzz pedal. Lol.

content:
Hey guys- so I’m asking this question I guess in a mixing context but I know it’s a common function of mastering so I thought I’d post here. 

I always have an instance of ozone maximizer at the end of my chain that I mix into. I’m generally happy with the results/loudness I get and comfortable with the parameters, except I never really mess with the “character” which I suppose is the speed/release of the limiting? 

On a recent mix I slowed it down more than I ever would, which really just means making it slower at all from the defaul setting, I usually stick very close to it, and I really like how it made the pocket of my mix feel. But I guess, I have always understood people to use very fast release compression on masterbusses.. 

do you all find yourselves moving the character/release of the final limiter around pretty widely to get the right feel or are you typically keeping it quite fast?

author: Moses Mastering
content: yes i will move attack and release all the time for every song depending on gear or plugin.. i actually think attack and release at mastering is kind of a make or break to a lot of my "sound"...... to dial in the groove of the song... also with that ozone  character slider if its fast it will have a tendency to distort if pushed hard. You can slow it down and get a cleaner sound ... and while you then lose a bit of volume you can then actually limit it more to make it back up. I notice when i move it to slow i lose about .2-.4 db in final level, so then I can gain it back up and take that "off" in the limiter. This might sound silly haha.. but it gets me the same "loudness" of the "loud" setting while being cleaner. Sometimes i just use loud though when it sounds right haha. this is not a perfect science but general observation and application haha.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Let's assume a few things

a) The artist loves their digital masters

b) Limiting and clipping cause challenges in cutting and more importantly playing back vinyl

It's a fact that we push most modern records to the limit loudness wise and they often beneift sonically from a few dB more breathing room.

So here I start with a default of 2dB less limiting. I'm comparing back and forth with the approved digital masters attenuated to match. Is it better? Is some element popping out?

author: hebakadry
content: I think time spent de-essing vocals and treating HF content in vinyl prepped masters overrides worrying about how much limiting there is in my opinion. The amount of limiting and how good/bad the cut is really pertinent on the program material itself.  Not the actual amount of gain reduction you are doing because the cutter will literally just turn everything down anywhere between 8-10dB before the signal hits the amps. Excessive sibilance, on a hyper compressed rock record with insane splashy over compressed cymbals and out of control HF information will result in the dull cuts you get back from most plants where you don’t have access to the cutting engineer.  They do this because they want to create a playback safe record and avoid a very expensive $10k mistake like blowing a cutterhead if their amp breakers aren’t calibrated right.  Instead of spot de-essing problem on one song or spot treating problem songs on a side, they will opt for broad stroke moves (HF limiting, EQ, global de-essing) and that can be a bit of death sentence to the quality of the cut and put everyone off vinyl as a format.  Which I think is an incredible format with well crafted engineering.  Also I strongly believe that every record doesn’t belong on vinyl…but that’s another convo.

author: hebakadry
content: If you don’t cut and you’re not sure... keep the limiting and let the cutter solve the issues.  If you have a relationship with a cutting engineer and want to see what works best, have them send an acetate where they cut a side with the limiter on full blast and the same exact program on another side with it pulled back and make a determination.  Transcribe the sides into your DAW and then flip between them and see what sounds best.  Don’t compare to the digital master…just use your ears.  Good cutting engineers are creative and may do some work to give you the “transparent” cut everyone’s after.  But it does require some crafty engineering and taste.

author: miguel @ knurlmastering
content:
I try not to change the hardware from song to song. The chain I create for each record defines the sonic character of the entire project. If I need track-specific adjustments, I’ll add plugins before the hardware chain. That way, each song is shaped to fit the chain I designed for the record. After the hardware, I will add plugins as well, typically something like limiting.

In the end, every song is tweaked individually. Often there are plugins for specific sections, along with level automation within the track. Once those adjustments are made, all songs then run through the hardware chain.

I always print the hardware chain, so when revisions come up (making something a little louder or quieter, or adjusting a fade-in or fade-out) I don’t need to recall the hardware.

author: BillyC
content: @Eric Martin @David Fuller I understand how digital clipping can occur, but I'm still not sure I understand how it's theoretically possible to have true headroom above 0dBfs. In my mind the converter either has a nifty way of limiting intersample peaks, or the converter is simply scaling the signal down by -2.5dBfs.

author: BillyC
content: Again, I can conceive of ISPs. My question is even simpler: Isn't a converter company claiming to have *true* 2.5dB above full scale being a bit disingenuous? Doesn't that actually only mean they have a good sounding way limiting ISPs up to 2.5dB above full scale? In other words, "yeah this exactly 6' person will absolutely fit into our exactly 6' tall room...right after we take off his shoes and give him a clean buzz cut." Maybe my question is more semantic?

author: David Fuller
content: https://www.audiosciencereview.com/forum/index.php?threads/help-explain-intersample-overs-please.11651/page-2#post-335404

author: David Fuller
content: tl;dr: AKM chips have extra headroom above the voltage level that AKM decides is full scale, so the converter itself cannot clip with lower ISPs. Given good analog side engineering around that, it won't clip until it hits about +2dBFS - and the clipping behavior is pretty benign compared to the utter tomfuckery that is ESS

author: ehutton21
content:
i know people swear by the boz big clipper but there’s a lot of ways to clip. standard clip by SIR is really good for situations where i don’t need to control attack and release etc and i love using it on vocals because it’s really gentle on the voice, it adds this really nice saturation i don’t find elsewhere, and it discourages you from going over the top.

Thanks man! So I do like ozone quite a bit actually. I'm not looking to totally replace it, but it's been my go to for years now and I think it's time I expanded my horizons... Add another tool or two to the arsenal you know.
How will you decide what limiter to use on a song? Is it kinda genre dependent or nothing that simple?

author: ehutton21
content:
comfort & best range of flexibility is my criteria. I prefer having attack and release controls and being able to tweak it all accordingly, and that’s why i’m keen on ozone and boz—ozone fits so seamlessly in with the rest of my bus compression as well. everyone does mix-bus differently and for me the biggest thing i want my clipper to do is to catch the peaks that my bus compressor hasn’t dealt with as in full and provide a little more “push” without squashing anything. for me, i try to keep mix bus processing pretty consistent in terms of tools but vary the control settings to match the song. pro-q (pulling down very subtle things i don’t want), bus compressor, my quick little ozone chain, and then the boz clipper.

it varies from genre to genre on occasion but most of the artists i work with have a very consistent “radio friendly” sound that’s kind of genre blending, so i get to work closely with them on determine the feel.

author: Zach Hughes
content: Folks, I have a question for the group. Would love to get a mastering engineers perspective. I'm curious what is the rationale behind masters clipping output converters and leaving in true peaks that exceed 0dBFS? I get that clipping converters can sound cool / desirable, but why not achieve the clipping you want and then print a final master under zero? Why risk a consumer product crapping out during playback and adding potential distortion and why totally disregard pretty much every DSP's recommendation that true peaks not exceed -1 for the encoding process? I'm noticing that a ton of major label releases are peaking above zero with loudness normalization turned off on Spotify.

author: Zack Hames
content:
I want to clear something up:

People say “your master will get turned down more”.

Yes. If your master is -8 LUFS it’ll get knocked down to -14.


If it’s -13 LUFS…it also gets knocked to -14 LUFS.

So two songs, regardless of their original loudness, will match. 

If you released the same song at two different LUFS, they’d end up sounding “the same” loudness wise after normalization. Not taking into account the compression/saturation that happens with extreme limiting. 


And honestly LUFS works. So just master your shit however it sounds and feels best. Whether that’s -6 or -10 or -16.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
Could be wrong but my understanding is that LUFS are relative to dBFS. If a master at -8 LUFS with a true peak of -1 dBFS (for the sake of simple math) was normalized to -14 LUFS the true peak of the normalized master would now output at -7 dBFS with loudness normalization turned on.

If the same song was mastered at -13 LUFS with the same true peak of -1 dBFS was normalized to -14 LUFS the true peak of the normalized master would now output to -2 dBFS with loudness normalization turned on.

These would not sound the same.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Peak values and LUFS are related but there’s not much to say beyond that. Obviously if you have a crazy low peak value like -2 dBFS then you will@have to limit the mix way too much to get a competitive level

author: Zach Hughes
content: I mean relative in that if you turned a -8LUFS mastered track down 1dB with your fader it would output -9LUFS. And if your master once normalized on Spotify is turned down then the true peak is lowered (if measuring system output from Spotify) the same decibel amount the track is turned down to reach -14 LUFS. The true peak of a track with greater dynamic range that is turned down less or not at all post normalization will be higher. So relative peak levels upon playback, with normalization on, of tracks mastered at varying LUFS values is what I mean.

author: Zack Hames
content:
14 LUFS is 14 LUFS is 14 LUFS.

2 songs that are both measured at 14 LUFS will feel very very similarly in level. The true peak makes 0 difference in this perception.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
I started mastering my first 12 song album yesterday. I've mastered other albums but 12 is the highest track count I've worked with on a project. I'm curious about other's approaches and work flows for mastering albums specifically.

I also have a more targeted question. I am wondering, in a world where most modern records take up all available headroom are relative track balance decisions (i.e. *I want the final chorus of track 3 to be the loudest perceived part of the entire album*) made at the input stage of the final limiter? Choosing less gain reduction via limiting or compression as well as distortion / saturation rather than turning a track down. Seems like a ratchet towards clipping, distortion, and lack of dynamic range and transient detail. Sure that's a whole can of worms but would be interested to discuss it. 🤘

author: masteredbyjack
content:
We did discuss a bit earlier but I’m not sure I understand your question — I think I read it as you looking into the trade off between turning down a more limited/compressed track (i.e to a dBFS level of like -.5 compared to where others are at) vs leaving the peak level and some more dynamics (which can also make a song sound quieter but in a different way)? 

IMO it’s just a gut feeling/listening game. Both approaches work but have different implications that have to be decided based on artistic intent.

But specifically for albums (and all mastering generally) working off intuition always works so much better for me. This also means you have to sort of practice outside of “game time” so the tools flow when in the moment. Able to work quicker so you keep the entire project in mind. Mastering is a game of trade offs both in songs themselves and between them.

Also IMO “cohesion” is totally overrated in mastering albums. I never care (or even know, honestly) as a listener if song 8 sounds cohesive with song 1. I just care that the arc of the album moves me

author: Zach Hughes
content: If track cohesion is out the window this doesn't really matter. However, if you care about the dynamics song to song on an album and the norm is that each track hits the same ceiling then it seems to me this would lead to needing to push the louder tracks harder and into a limiter potentially introducing more distortion and decreasing dynamic range. I guess I'm butting up against the norm of allowing all tracks to share the same output ceiling.

author: spectrummasters
content:
@Nomograph Mastering  right, ruari class finished ! .....ok so, ive a lot of thoughts ...this exercise has made a v big impression on me .
Off top, 

According to RX The mix is at -7.2 LUFS integrated , -6.3 short term, TP -0.1

The artist wants a "bit more low-end " on a fast paced, alt/pop/rock track.
And Imo a little air on top would compliment the mix.
(starting at -7.2 is loud for my experience so its a good challenge and these sort of Lufs are what i want to become v comfortable working at where currently im more comfortable around -9.)

SO i start with your 10 eq points in place , with your q settings and .5 db limits in fabfilter pro q 3  .

Thoughts:

It became clear immediately how powerful to me these q settings and eq points are, with regards to re-shaping the tonal balance.
I cannot recall ever having only used these curves , nor in the absence of any other processing. 
Listening to the impact of 0.1 db up or down in the different areas was remarkable. 

After half an hour id got to something i was v happy with, that appeared "Louder " to me and also.....a bit more lows and a little more open on top. Which id call a success.

Id brought the Pro q output down 0.4db to compensate the gain increase and printed with no limiter.

In RX this printed version showed as -7.2 LUFS integrated , -6.3 short term, TP 0.0 .

Ideally id have not touched this again.....i really liked it. 

Following instructions i then put the L2 Limiter on (modern mode , +0.1 db, TP on and output -0.1) .

Truth be told, once id put the limiter on i wanted to go back into the EQ because i didnt like the sound anymore, i felt the L2 spoilt it.

author: ALXCPH
content:
The only things I can advise on is based on personal experience. And many people have lots of different takes on this. 

But my advice is to not even worry about the concept of mastering at this point in their musical journey and just make the best music they can, and put as much effort into it as humanly possible to make it sound to the best of their ability. And then slap a limiter on it to get it as loud as they can get it before it starts sounding worse. Make mix changes based on what they don’t like when testing it on different systems. 

And while it might not sounds like a the weeknd record mastered by sing, it should still be able to be somewhat competitive to other people at the same level. 

Reps will teach them something new every time. And finding a mentor will also do the same. If they can an attended mastering session with someone who does great work, it could give some great insight about the possibilities and function of what mastering actually does. 

This might be a bit of a hot take, but if a track sounds very far from release ready before mastering, it’s probably not ready to be mastered yet.

I think this is the biggest thing. Sometimes I can tell that a mixer really intentionally used some limiting and it’s a big part of the vibe, they are making very big decisions through it, shaping transients, etc. So why go back from that?

But more often it’s as you said Cian, limiter is just thrown on. And is not creatively essential to the sound and feel.

Again, I am pretty new but I can usually tell pretty quickly when trying to “beat” the ref which category it falls in.

And I’m always trying to do it with my own chain, but sometimes the feel is right there already. It’s certainly never a choice of what is easier, it’s a choice of what feels better to me and which I “believe” more

content: @Nomograph Mastering  hi ruairi so I’m on my third listen to “tunnel under ocean boulevard “ and have been really enjoying it . It’s got a vibe of  a david lynch movie about a singer who is the love child of dusty Springfield and Elvis who grew up with Kate bush on tour with Tom waits and roger waters . Anyhoo I digress ! If I may ask as much as poss without asking you to divulge anything compromising about the process : I am fascinated by a few things and wonder what your approach was . In many parts this work feels almost like a  poetry with orchestration and I think has extended parts with little or quite subtle drum parts . I wonder with something like this how do you judge how hard (or not ) to push the overall level (both individual tracks and all together ) as for me I think I tend to judge off what the drums / bass dictates w/regard to level . In this case where drums and bass aren’t really dominating , I’m not sure I’d be as confident in knowing what is the right level . After all there are periods of soft vocal and very gentle lush strings …..these sorts of passages I might get a bit unsure In . I also wondered did you stay in the box for this one ? ….and was this a project for mostly eq more than comp/limiting ? The sound of the record is v expensive and classic imo , do you treat a record like this completely differently with regards to what processes you might use on a different genre (again ITB vs analogue chains ) . author: Jodonny
content: My mindset is that I'm looking to control inconsistencies in various stages throughout a mix. I don't want random peaks going into my mix bus processing. Clipping to me just sounds better than limiting on transient-focused material, such as drums. A good trick I've found and use regularly is to add subtle transient shaping post clipping to bring some life back in.

author: Jodonny
content: For non-drums, I use L1 a ton because it sounds "smoother" in a lot of cases. Still some transient shaping post limiting. Do this all the time throughout a mix

author: Jodonny
content: Clip gaining is a different thing. That's pre processing and sounds stacking up on each other. When a waveform from one part of a high hat loop happens to overlap a certain snare hit it can bring out higher levels than what the whole drum bus has been doing on average. Clipping averages out those peaks.

author: Rob Domos

author: Rob Domos

author: Jodonny
content: I like the overall sound of clipping and dirty drums on most songs I do, so I'm not just doing it for peak control. But this "peak control" premise applies to all sounds in mixing. I first started thinking of it when I saw Pensado use 3 L1's in a row on a live bass. You're slowly evening out the sound.

author: sethearnest

Question to the mastering minds on here from a mixer who has to self-master often: when pushing a solo piano (or piano-focused arrangement) into 'very loud' territory, limiters seem especially sensitive to pianos and get to crackling faster than with most any other instrument. 

My thoughts as to why: 
1) the inherent dynamic range of the instrument (attack vs sustain of it)
2) The amount of midrange frequency build up inherent to the instrument and overtones created
3) Often, the music styles I'm referring to will be orchestral or film score ish, so any amount of distortion is noticed more quickly than the natural masking that can occur in something like a rock track

FF ProL2 seems especially sensitive to pianos, and I'll often reach for something else when it's a piano-heavy arrangement.

Is there something else I'm not thinking about in this area? 

(This is all under the umbrella of knowing how to do loud well w/the understanding that often times our solo piano Icaruses don't need get that close to the sun, and I can just back it off a couple dB. I'm just trying to understand why limiters seem to fall apart so quickly specifically w/pianos.)

author: cian riordan
content: I may not have your reps, but I have yet to have an album come across my desk that I prep for vinyl that doesn’t sound better with 5 dB less limiting. I get that our line of work is constantly trying to shovel shit rolling down the hill at us, but I think there’s more nuance than “modern records are loud and need to stay loud otherwise they fall apart.” Vinyl isn’t a medium that was designed with -7 or -9 LUFS in mind… and I have yet to hear a vinyl pressing cut in this contemporary fashion that doesn’t sound like a pile of assholes. I have lots of time for serving the client and the project, being a team player and getting things across the line.. but that’s usually the reality of the business... not what’s best for the Sonics. I think vinyl has the opportunity to sound amazing but modern mixing AND mastering techniques are often getting in the way of that.

author: hebakadry
content: Some dance records can sound fine with some limiting or clipping still on…but that’s because there are no vocals and the crest factor is for the most part pretty high and you can get away with it.  The pickup playback distortion can also create harmonics and ends up bringing back some of the high frequency information you may lose as the you progress towards the inner diameter, but the moment you add female vocals on, it becomes very perceptible.

author: hebakadry
content: Also you have to remember most cuts are being cut by engineers at cutting plants where the processing happens in a separate rooms from where the actual lathe is…it’s very “factory” and they will really not go above and beyond to solve issues except just literally turning down the master even more, HF limiting and de-essing the hell out of it’s life.

author: Adam Thein
content:
I’ll take a stab, I’m sure others can chime in to add more to this:

Mastering is the final step in record making - typically with an engineer who has yet to hear the song in its final form.

The mastering stage is often where a track is set to its final level, quality controlled for technical issues (unintentional noise), and often subjectively sweetened or tonally shifted based on the taste of the engineer.

The actual processing involved can vary widely but often engineers are relying on EQ and limiting most prominently, although they may also reach for non linear processors such as compression, saturation, and other coloring tools.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Okay crew got a question on a scenario I’ve come upon often enough to ask:

A limited REF is given at 24 bit — but when the non-lim mix is given in 24bit it’s peaking at exactly 0.0db. 

Obviously there could be many explanations for this (if intentional, which is fine). But I’ve had it happen quite a few times where I have a close relationship with a mixer and thought it could be an oversight for reasons specific to each instance (not just generally seeing a peak of 0)— turns out when the non-lim 32 bit print is sent there are sure enough overs in there.

Typically i see it happen when they are going into limiters hot in the REF, obviously when they print non-lim there are overs. Talking big overs, +4db or whatever

BUT — honestly it doesn’t really sound “clipped” in the 24bit non-lim print — I’m assuming the overs are just recalibrated to zero but somehow this doesn’t sound bad? Of course, if I get the 32bit I find I can make it sound just as loud but “better” with the full waveform represented in the 32bit file.

It’s an easy fix — just get a 32 bit print without a limiter (if I can get in touch with who is handling that, which isn’t always the case).

I think (?) I understand what’s happening — DAWs operate at 64 or 32 and can handle the overs fine in the session, but upon render at 24bit they get chopped (not sure about wording).

Totally fine — I can and have handled it no problem, just a curiosity on what others are seeing, if I’m even on the mark about this and how (or if) you are handling it.

author: cian riordan
content: They might be clipping the non-lim in an analog chain? Or a digital chain?

author: masteredbyjack
content: Usually I don’t worry about it and assume intentionally clipped — there have just oddly been cases recently where I looked into it for a specific reason (clipping acoustic ballad or whatever which made me wonder) and it wasn’t intentional, so it makes me wonder if others have seen this too

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: But very often someone will build a mix and the limiter will be catching overs and removing means overs that get committed on a fixed point print

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: - if your limiter is doing more than 3 or 4dB of gain reduction figure out why and see if you can control that element at source

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: - when it comes time to Master you have to understand that you are missing the most essential component - objectivity. So give your self a break between mix and master time. Try to minimize the processing at this stage - I would focus on the right EQ and limiter settings (you can work for unlimited versions of your mixes but use the same limiter)

author: Jonathan Jetter

author: masteredbyjack
content:
From my understanding and tests, yes if it is imported in a DAW and changed at all, we are now in 32 or 64 bit land. Will you hear this difference? Most likely no like Ruairi said, it would have to be a very specific case.

Over here I always dither after export in RX, so it solves that issue. And for an album I’ll print the whole thing to a separate montage so if it’s just spacing or whatever that needs to change, it’s easy enough and no re-rendering of plugins is necessary (and Wavelab seems to handle seamless transitions better this way)

I’ve seen a fair amount of non-limited mixes that I find out are truncated to 24 bit depth — any over zeros that a limiter was catching go to zero — and even then it usually doesn’t really sound horrible since it’s often a very fast transient peak. But something to be aware of

author: aidanthillmann
content:
Hi, I’m not a mastering engineer but I did a sort of mastering experiment recently:

I was watching the Mix with the Masters videos with Randy Merrill and Idania Valencia, and I noticed that they were using plain old input gain before their limiter to push it instead of increasing the threshold of the limiter itself, so their limiter thresholds/gains were at 0. I thought maybe they knew something I didn’t.

So I tried it. I put a gain plugin before my limiter and pushed the limiter with it. The results? It sounds awful. All the punch and width is gone. Change back to using the limiter’s threshold, sounds great.

Any technical reason for this? I was using the Kilohearts Gain plugin in to Ozone Maximizer, but I would be hard pressed if it was one of those plugins at fault. Maybe the threshold of the limiter has an internal signal flow that changes its behavior as opposed to gain coming in to it or something? Maybe this workflow makes better sense in Sequoia for the Sterling engineers for some reason?

author: masteredbyjack
content: I actually believe @cian riordan mentioned here before that there IS something different about how the Ozone maximizer reacts to pushing gain into it with threshold at 0 vs using the input gain. For my workflow, when I use it I'm pushing into it with the input gain, so I'd have to do some tests. But for other limiters (limitless, Pro L2), I haven't noticed a big difference between what you're suggesting -- very open to being wrong about that though!

author: Joshua Riley
content:
Main takeaways: 

Always get a second opinion 
Let your emotions cool down before you respond to an artist 

Context: 

An artist I work with regularly has a relatively small budget and isn’t the most experienced with the mix/master side. 
Every track I’ve mixed for him, he’s had it mastered for free by an ME. Two songs ago he got onto experimenting with AI mastering which he thankfully moved off of because the tracks sounded horrible. 
This last track we did, he had another ME offer to do a test master on it. I was down and just asked if I could hear it before it goes out. Fast forward, he uploads the track and the first time I hear about it was through socials. So I asked if he went with that ME and how it sounded and got told no, his drummer mate ended up mastering the track. 
So I just got quite frustrated as him and I have quite an open relationship. Mainly because it didn’t sound that great. There was a bunch of true peak overs which thankfully I’m less stressed about after speaking to Jack
So I’m struggling to see if this is ego or just that I don’t trust this person who mastered the track.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
I believe I’ve seen this video, and have a theory (which I feel free to be proven wrong on and I’m sure you know all this, but to jam on it here).

DAW probably can represent the overs fine without clipping, inside it is 32 or 64 bit like @Nomograph Mastering . Then in render to 16 bit the overs just get put to 0 (“quantized”?). So clipped but not digitally distorted…or at least the bad digital distortion we think of

I’ve seen this in quite a few mixes where the limiter is removed on a mix sent to me at 24bit. In fact I’ve seen people “clip” up to 6db unknowingly doing this and it honestly sounds…fine? Like not some wild digital distortion. I was able to get the 32bit print and verify

author: masteredbyjack

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Alright I'm back with another question for the hive mind:

Finishing up an EP today we've been slow-dripping for awhile. First song we did had big drums, tons of low, measures louder (-8.4 LUFS). Mastered and approved before the rest of them came this way. Rest of the songs are sparse, open, beautiful. But accordingly meausre much lower (loudest is -11 LUFS). 

So with the new info Dale posted the other day re: how Spotify is normalizing levels, I thought let's just turn down the louder one a little to see how it fits (it's fine), maybe that can buy us a db or whatever for the other songs when they normalize to the loudest song as long as the creative intent is preserved (it is). And that's cool. But actually a better result IMO was to just ease up on the loudness of the first song (at -8.4 LUFS), it makes more sense in the project being a bit more dynamic rather than having the dense one be pulled down.

Question is: will this cause the single version to be replaced by the new album one when going to distro?

I've had masters that we replaced before with a lowered ceiling in projects and all was fine, but the actual master was exactly the same minus the ceiling, so in a single context it would normalize the same. I know to keep exact length to ms, etc etc. 

But the new info Dale posted makes me rethink how to handle this in albums (on Spotify -- on Apple is doesn't seem to be doing that?)

author: Montano Mastering
content:
New to the discord here but just read through the ADM chat and have an interesting follow up.

I am certified to provide ADM. About a year ago I noticed that a label I work with was submitting my non-ADM files to Apple as ADM and still getting certified. I asked the label to use the ADM files in the future as I didnt want to risk my accreditation. They responded that nothing had been flagged by distribution nor by Apple but they would do so moving forward.

Flash forward to this year - I noticed that some ADM files from other engineers had overs, not just clipping but significant overs, check the newest Olivia Rodrigo album. According to the aforementioned document, definitely not to spec hahah.

Flash forward from there to about a month ago, I submitted my standard formats to another label I work with including standard streaming WAV as well as an ADM file. author: Nomograph Mastering

If you have the time then nothing beats RX. The issue with that kind of top end is not how much of it there is, it’s the character. The inharmonic and dense nature of the sound, mostly caused by particular types of clipping and distortion

Pretty much every other tool attenuates based on how much of a given frequency band there is, and so is pretty ineffective - tending to vacillate between not enough and too much
