author: masteredbyjack
content:
I don't use that plugin -- but I absolutely will master things loudness matched to the REF just using Wavelab. And certainly listen to level matched often (I like Loudness Penalty Studio for something outside the DAW that's easy). Once I get it to the volume of the REF I'll just use the linked limiting input/output to keep it at the level of the REF to understand if what I'm adding in level and processing is making it better. Of course not on everything, but with stuff that's really hot already I find it very useful! To be sure that we are making it better not just louder, louder is usually quite easy (but can often translate quieter)

And I'll turn in things quieter if I think it's better too. Rarely but I certainly have done it with a short note like @Nomograph Mastering mentioned before "thought x thing that was awesome about this felt better at this density"

author: Rollmottle
content:
If I don’t have a hot ref, sometimes at the end when I think I’m done, I’ll dupe the mix, delete the processing, gain it accordingly and copy my limiter to it to compare. Nothing that scientific but all done by feel and ear. 

I don’t listen to the hot ref until the very end after I’ve made all my decisions so I can let the song take me where it needs to go vs shooting for a target.

author: Zach Hughes
content: In part, I think it comes down to different ideas of how to achieve success. Incentives. False proxies. Varying time horizons. I want to work slower and aim higher. Often those coming through the door seem to feel they must work at greater speed, that they are behind somehow. For context I work mainly with independent artists with very limited resources. I can't get the question 'why don't we all rely on each other more?' out of my head lately. I want for more organization. I want to be on the hook with others who feel likewise.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content:
Could be several different things, right? Sometimes it's a gap too far to bridge in the moment- I'd love some upper extensions on the harmony but the artist only thinks in triads. Sometimes it's a technical limitation- the rough mix is a mess but I know the producer's assembling the track on Focal Alphas in an untreated room. Sometimes it's a budget limitation or label politics that I'll never know about. Sometimes (often) different people just think about music differently. Sometimes (often) it's none of my business, and I should focus my energy on my part of the job.

Also try to have enough self-awareness to remember that I surely have my own analogous blind spots.

And also 110% believe in empowering one's collaborators, helping people learn and make progress. I just don't think in-the-moment critiques are a helpful part of that.

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: While I don't do that in the sense of smashing things on 2 limiters I do often use 2 limiters with one only catching occasional peaks. On a lot of what I work on that has tons of low end I might get things feeling good with one limiter but then there might be the occasional peak that makes it crunch up so rather than fussing with it (and making it not work as well for 90% of the time) I'll have another limiter bring down those peaks and get things not crunching. author: nachomaquieira
content: Hi everyone! Today I thought I’d write here to ask how you approach mastering an album that you've mixed yourself. Sometimes I work on albums where the mixes are done in a very short time, and other times it takes longer, so the focus changes over time (which is totally natural). Right now, what I’m doing is setting up a mastering session with all the latest mixes (with limiting applied), doing the track list, and listening to the differences between them—things like timbre, balance, loudness, etc. I make notes of what I hear, then go back to the mix sessions to make small tweaks. After that, I export everything without the final clipping/limiting on the tracks, so I can apply those in the final mastering session and then master the album. Anyone with a different approach is more than welcome to share, as right now I’m wrapping up a lot of albums I’ve worked on throughout the year, and I want to stay as sharp as possible to give them a proper finish.

author: vostral
content: "The problem with upward expansion is that if you are trying to make a recording hot, you must follow the expander with a limiter to increase the level, but the limiter will fight the advantages of the expander, and soon becomes the limiting factor. When the limiter is used conservatively, it will not deteriorate the sharp transients, and the upward expander can do its job of making the upward-going dynamics more exciting. Prove it by bypassing the limiter at matched compare levels and see if it's hurting the sound of the music. If it is, and you cannot live with the degradation, the only solution is to master at a lower level. "

author: Elaine Rasnake
content:
Generally when I've had to master files for someone to press to vinyl, I will take the limiter off and create  designated A side / B Side files along with a PQ sheet of all of the start/stop times, album order, and things like that via HOFA DDP Maker.
I leave all of the high end low end adjustments to the pressing engineer since they will know best what needs to be adjusted, if at all. 

I know of some folks who also just send the limited "digital distro" files but I prefer to give a more dynamic version and the pressing engineer can adjust it.

Usually an artist will go through test pressings and if there are issues, usually (or at least ideally) the pressing engineer, the artist, and the mastering engineer are all communicating about things and next steps

I'm curious if this idea, since I often see the whole "remove the limiter for vinyl" advice, was more like saying remove the limiter so then the pressing engineer could add their own to bring that digital distro character back but have the control of easing up on it and doing needed to be done for the vinyl itself. 

But it does make sense in a way to just ease up on it and  leave some of the character of the limiter there from the get-go.

author: Grover
content:
If that much limiting is happening then sure, it's part of the music. My experience is mainly with two situations:

1. The digital mastering engineer is the same as the cutting engineer. Artists were not bypassed in getting the vinyl cut approved. They listened to and signed off on both. 

2. The digital and cutting engineer were working closely together. 

Now, a lot of these artists were not making music that required massive amounts of limiting to sound the way they do. 

That said, I disagree. Vinyl is already changing the sound so radically that if sonic faithfulness to the digital master is required - why make vinyl? A record will NEVER sound like the digital original or even the tape master for that matter. No two lathes sound anything alike, and the differences can be astonishing. I have heard a lathe amp turn a wretched sounding track into a brilliant one. And vice versa. Vinyl is an unfaithful medium. If you don't care about the cut's sound that's fine. Submit whatever is submitted for the digital master and let the pressing house sort it out. Why even bother with a proper 3rd party cutting engineer at that point?

author: Grover
content:
Bob and Ian's opinions on "audiophiley" music are of no functional interest to me. I'm not advocating for that in either digital or vinyl mastering. 

And I get it - I know and have worked with several really talented and very busy cutting engineers, and I take it seriously as well. 

A question was asked regarding how to prepare masters. A good friend of mine is one of the top Lathe techs in North America, and my understanding from him and the cutting engineers I know and have worked with, is that digital clipping can make life hard for lathes. I'm not saying you cannot do it or arguing the merits of digital limiting or anything like that, that's an entirely separate topic. It is however a technical fact that lathes do not get along well with digital clipping and it will make the cutting engineers job harder and generally result in a record which does not sound as dynamic. If that is an acceptable compromise then so be it. As you say, if the artist/client is happy and the bills are paid, then all is well (mostly 😉)

author: Paris Lee
content: ‘Riding the distortion’ is such an important thing- when the timing of the distortion is locked within the ‘groove of the record’ then it is much less noticeable and poking out to our ears and you can go a little harder. Delta plugins can be very beneficial- this goes for clipping and de essing also. Listen to the ‘delta’ (can be annoying and not so great for your hearing so don’t do it a long time) and get your distortion in rhythm with the record. I guess the best way to describe that is when you get that sort of wobble where you can’t hear everything (duh you’re hearing only the added distortion) but the gaps fill in in your mind and you can follow the timing- then you’ll be happy with the result plus the trade offs induced.

author: hebakadry
content: Ultimately it’s the material itself that should be considered not like a rule of thumb thing that works for every single album.  Like a hot dance/techno record with no vocals will cut really beautifully with all the limiting intact…if anything, the tracing playback distortion will bring back some harmonics lost and make some HH or snares crunch in a really pleasing way.  On a really congested rock record with very low crest factor and really upfront vocals, pulling back limiting does actually help and gives a little bit of head room to not expose as many artefacts on playback.

Hip hop is almost unique in the limiting being a huge technical aspect of the genre. I continue to master hip hop although I have not as of yet, cut any. 
My standard procedure for making a digital master for lacquer cutting is simply to render the sides without limiting. 
Ive have had exactly one client that thought the test pressing sounded too dynamic so I resent the files but with some limiting retained although not the full monte. If you heard the music you would have NEVER guessed this twist in the story. 
@hebakadry is correct that highs are a bigger deal. I guess the point is every project has unique characteristics that require the person cutting it to sometimes make decisions that blur technical and artistic ones together. This is partly why I have a policy of cutting only masters I’ve done. I feel I have the liberty of eq’ing some more at cutting time. 
So as far as the comments go, nobody is totally wrong - it’s simply very situation dependent. I would advise a few things:.

The challenging part in mastering is that at a very minute level all of the tools a mastering engineer has do affect the sound. I suppose I was a bit caught off guard by Nomograph's positing that heavy limiting at the mastering stage to affect the groove (maybe I misunderstood that comment) is pretty much the standard. author: vostral
content:
I just export/ render a master at two different sample rates. 48k (original project SR) and 96k (for experimenting). And the result is the 96k master has more powerful and solid low end, which i'm pretty into and surprised too. 

How is that possible???

FYI, i have turned on oversampling in the clippers and limiter

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Several possible mechanisms for the change

- Less aliasing (making things feeling more weighty)
- The sound of the oversampling filters (blurring top end transients and "smoothing" the lows)
- A bug/difference in how a plug in is working at the new sample rate

If Just SRCing to 96k was a free lunch we'd all be doing it every day, so it's worth trying to understand the reaons for what you hear. That way you can employ it when appropriate in the future

author: Berlin
content:
Vinyl itself has its own limitations, and most of them are in the playback, and not the cutting. The groove can contain much more information than the playback needle can handle (i.e. out of phase sub signals - they can likely be cut, but they can't be played back well on most systems). - I say that to say that Lacquer can handle anything that you want to give it. 

My suggestion is to link up with a cutting engineer - whether lacquer or DMM, communicate your sonic desires, and let them do their work. If you can find someone great that's local to you, perhaps you can attend and put your ears on a test cut.

author: conordalton
content:
I feel like I can hear a difference between different dither types. So if I can hear the difference between different dither types then I can hear the dither or at least the effect of the dither on the song (sometimes) 

The question is if the quantization distortion is more or less audible than the dither noise at loud sections of the song, and if the quantization distortion is less audible than the dither then it makes a case for automating the dither to when it’s actually necessary (the quiet sections of the song)

But that’s at the limit of my understanding and knowledge on the subject so I welcome your thoughts and experience about it

author: Juliette
content:
Learning a little bit more about the use of limiters these last couple of weeks in order to get your mix louder (not going down the rabbit hole of loudness today though.) Also, is all clipping inherently *bad*, depending on how much you’re clipping?

author: Slow Hand
content:
I'm not doing much limiting on my master buss. As I'm working I might be catching 6 dB of peaks, but by the time things are mixed I'm getting the loudness at the source instruments or instrument group. My master buss might be averaging 3 dB of gain reduction at the end. If I have heavy transients from the drums hitting my limiter I'll limit the drum group so it's not ducking the entire mix when they hit.

I don't use clippers at all. To my ears they reliably make things sound like mush, but other people seem to get good results with them.

When it comes time to master, I'll turn down my limiter and pass it to the ME. Confident that my balance isn't dependent on everything being smushed into a limiter.

author: Juliette
content: Interesting, very good insight! And yeah, the more I’ve been studying, the more I’ve seen lots of engineers opting to limits particular areas rather than the entire track itself. Which honestly makes more sense if your overall master isn’t an issue.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
(copy/paste)

Assuming we're talking about fairly typical rock, pop and Hip Hop then this 3 part strategy covers a lot of ground

1) Make sure the EQ is as balanced as you can get it - most of your perceived loudness comes from the arrangement and mid range focus (2k to 8k). Too much low end will sound bad when you limit. Make sure the relationship between 80, 160 and 320 makes sense (think of them a little like fundamental, 1st and 2nd harmonic).

2) Consider shaving snare transients (and maybe kick transients) with a clipper. This spreads that peak energy harmonically across the spectrum, keeping energy, hiding in the noisey nature of snares and lets the limiter work less hard (I like SIR Standardclip - $25, great metering and responds intuitively). a dB or two of clipping will help the limiter work less.

3) Pro-L2 on the settings below is a great start point for clean and predictable limiting, raising input gain until you get the desired level

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Then dial the Gain on Pro-L to give you the limiting and level you want

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: But simplifying even more … low end eats headroom in mixing, and making sure it’s not too wild will help get some overall level without a limiter pancaking

author: Val ᶠʳ
content:
Sometimes, I'm wondering what exactly happens when the gain reduction graph in Pro-L2 is not returning to unity and shows, for example, 1 or 2 dBs of "constant reduction" in between peaks. (Like in the picture attached.)

I used to avoid this kind of situation, thinking I was just reducing the whole volume of the track by 1 or 2 dBs, but judging by ear, and listening to the delta channel, it does not seem to be true. It feels more like I'm engaging the "clipping stage" a bit more (if we can call it this way).
It seems like above 3dBs of "constant limiting", then, the loudness hit a ceiling, and the volume is reduced proportionally. (Apparently this behavior change a bit across the different algorithms) 

Am I missing something ?
Should I stop paying attention to this graph, and use the "compact mode" of the GUI ? 🙂

author: Jonathan Jetter
content:
This is either you engaging the slower release stage and/or you limiting sufficiently heavily that it’s hitting the body of the signal and not just the peaks.

Probably the latter moreso than the former, but likely some of both.

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
My last update on this - How the first go went.

I ended up tweaking things throughout the sesh, and kept a lot of what was said here in mind as I navigated settings and mindsets.

These plugins will all be in a template inactive, but it helps me account for a lot of possible scenarios I could come across and how I'd approach it.

Here are the strokes I ended up doing for this test:

1. I did end up using RX and Soothe for this, since the test was a one take with many flaws.
2. MB did heavy lifting for control
3. I did a smiley face EQ on it and it felt appropriate, but also because of the lack of mixing on the raw one-take. 
4. ShadowHills 0.5-1.5dB on optical and discrete rebalanced at different levels felt like it added a sense of dimension that wasn't there.
5. Studer - Added, but again keeping in mind that it added characteristics I need to be careful putting onto a refined mix. This gave it some harmonic life it was missing.
6. Pro-DS - made some horrendous high end sound more bearable.
7. Pro-Q3 - some last lil notches for problem frequencies, especially up high and unpleasant.
8. Oxford Limiter - barely dancing thresh, slower attack, fast rls, inflator 42%, cus I'm spicy.

-

If anyone reads this and has comments or statements about any of this, please let me know if you'd like to give thoughts here, or if you'd like me to send you the before and after to gauge my decisions relative to your taste, based on the decisions I made for this file.

author: Berlin

If you want you can implement 2x oversampling to help mitigate ISP a little, but if you wanted a little more control, you can upsample and work at that high sample rate. Export at that higher sample rate, and 32bit float.

SRC and Dither using RX for your various formats.

Reassemble in your DAW for each program. i.e. Main Master, DDP, or Vinyl Premaster.

Find a workflow that works for
you.

Lots of folks don’t worry about these things and just export, listen and party. 🎉

There’s a lot of tweak-ability with Standard Clip’s oversampling and filter. Personally, I’d get my ears familiar with the oversampling amounts and the non-over sampled setting in the plugin. Some of those settings are pretty hard to differentiate, but some have clear differences. The clipping will sound different.

Then I’d play with default linear phase vs minimum phase oversampling filter. That difference is readily apparent to my ears. 

The slope and frequency of the filters have an incredible amount of variability. There are a staggering amount of possible settings. I can’t offer much on the sound of those changes. Maybe others can offer more insight.
